chapter.title: Databases
chapter.para:
Ubuntu provides two Database servers. They are:
MySQL
PostgreSQL
They are available in the main repository. This section explains how to install and configure these database servers.

sect1.title: MySQL
sect1.para: MySQL is a fast, multi-threaded, multi-user, and robust SQL database server. It is intended for mission-critical, heavy-load production systems as well as for embedding into mass-deployed software.

sect2.title: Configuration
sect2.para: By default, the administrator password is not set. Once you install MySQL, the first thing you must do is to configure the MySQL administrator password. To do this, run the following commands:

screen.command: sudo mysqladmin -p -u root -h localhost password newrootsqlpassword

sect2.para: You can edit the /etc/mysql/my.cnf file to configure the basic settings -- log file, port number, etc. Refer to /etc/mysql/my.cnf file for more details.

sect1.title: PostgreSQL
sect1.para: PostgreSQL is an object-relational database system that has the features of traditional commercial database systems with enhancements to be found in next-generation DBMS systems.

sect2.title: Configuration
sect2.para: By default, connection via TCP/IP is disabled. PostgreSQL supports multiple client authentication methods. By default, IDENT authentication method is used. Please refer the PostgreSQL Administrator's Guide.

The following discussion assumes that you wish to enable TCP/IP connections and use the MD5 method for client authentication. PostgreSQL configuration files are stored in the /etc/postgresql/<version>/main directory. For example, if you install PostgreSQL 7.4, the configuration files are stored in the /etc/postgresql/7.4/main directory.

tip.para: To configure ident authentication, add entries to the /etc/postgresql/7.4/main/pg_ident.conf file.

sect2.para: To enable TCP/IP connections, edit the file /etc/postgresql/7.4/main/postgresql.conf

Locate the line #tcpip_socket = false and change it to tcpip_socket = true. You may also edit all other parameters, if you know what you are doing! For details, refer to the configuration file or to the PostgreSQL documentation.

By default, the user credentials are not set for MD5 client authentication. So, first it is necessary to configure the PostgreSQL server to use trust client authentication, connect to the database, configure the password, and revert the configuration back to use MD5 client authentication.
